case_vignette: A 43-year-old woman comes to the ph   ysician because of a 2-month history of chest pain. She describes the pain as intermittent and burning-like. multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been experiencing intermittent burning-like chest pain and although I've tried medication, there has been no relief. I also have tightness of the skin on my fingers and small nonhealing ulcers on thickened skin of my fingertips. Additionally, there are fine crackling sounds heard in my lungs when breathing in. Lastly, I've noticed some mild tenderness when pressing on the upper middle area of my stomach.
Have you noticed any changes in your facial features, like tightness or thickening of the skin on your face?
No, I have not noticed any changes in the tightness or thickening of the skin on my face.
Do you have a history of acid reflux or heartburn?
Yes, I've tried using proton pump inhibitors for my symptoms.
Do you have any relatives with similar symptoms or any known autoimmune diseases?
I didn't mention any family history of similar symptoms or autoimmune diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
